title: Melbourne suburbs buyers should target: John McGrath’s top five
text:
A former “working class” inner suburb should be at the top of Melbourne buyers’ hit lists, one of Australia’s most famous real estate agents has declared.

Kensington leads John McGrath’s top picks in the latest McGrath Report, followed by southeastern suburbs Carnegie and Cheltenham, “often forgotten pocket of Melbourne’s northeast” Watsonia, and outer eastern spot Upwey.

The founder of national agency McGrath Real Estate — who’s previously appeared as a judge on The Block and an investor on Shark Tank — said Melbourne’s broader property market had rebounded in the second half of 2019.

The Federal election result, two interest rate cuts and improved lending conditions had helped stimulate the recovery from a downturn that wiped 10.9 per cent from dwelling values from the November 2017 market peak, he said in the report.

The city’s nation-leading population growth, affordability compared to Sydney, attractive job prospects, “buzzing” cafe and restaurant scene, and glamorous new apartment developments like St Kilda’s Saint Moritz held it in strong stead for future growth.

Mr McGrath said Kensington in particular offered “plenty of upside” for buyers — especially after its median house price shed 11.6 per cent in the year to June 30 to hit $895,000.

The northwestern suburb’s “grand Victorian architecture”, 10ha park and 4km commute to the CBD also made it aspirational for young families, he said.

“We’ve seen significant gentrification following the closure of the Newmarket Saleyards in 1984,” Mr McGrath said.

“Household incomes (have also been) on the rise as residents’ occupations have shifted from manufacturing to professional services.”

In Watsonia, a reduced median house price had also improved affordability, the leading agent said. The figure fell 18.3 per cent to $720,000 in the year to June 30.

Mr McGrath highlighted Watsonia’s “quiet and unassuming 1970s suburban streetscapes”, and the fact the upcoming North East Link was expected to cut the road commute for residents by up to 35 minutes.

Carnegie’s multicultural eat street on Koornang Rd earned it a guernsey, along with its quality public and catholic schools, and tram and train links.

Mr McGrath said nearby Cheltenham offered houses for less than $1 million, making it an affordable alternative to neighbouring Hampton and Beaumaris.

It had been further buoyed by the opening of the Southland train station in 2017 and Westfield Southland’s recent expansion.

Making Upwey attractive were its “outdoor lifestyle, community village atmosphere and affordable median house price of $687,000”, Mr McGrath said.

The straightforward 50-minute commute to Flinders St station on express trains was also luring professionals and tradies, with “hip cafes and restaurants” including vegetarian cafe Nevedya and “micropub” The Fat Goat reflective of the younger demographic.
